abstract: Analysis of skulls in in 3,000 year-old cemetery on Vanuatu Island in South Pacific, published in Proceedings of the National Academy of Science, concludes island's earliest residents likely descended from Asian and Polynesian populations; findings indicate modern residents of island bear more similarities to people in Melanesia; cemetery is oldest in South Pacific.
lead_paragraph: Skull analysis suggests the earliest inhabitants may have had Asian and Polynesian roots, while modern residents are more similar to Melanesians.

headline.main: The Residents of Vanuatu, Then and Now
headline.print_headline: Archaeology: The Residents of Vanuatu, Then and Now

snippet: Skull analysis suggests the earliest inhabitants may have had Asian and Polynesian roots, while modern residents are more similar to Melanesians.
